title: Letitia James
content:

from the [[New York City's 35th City Council district|35th]] district | term_start2 = January 1, 2004 | term_end2 = December 31, 2013 | predecessor2 = [[James E. Davis (councilman)|James E. Davis]] | successor2 = [[Laurie Cumbo]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|10|18}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | party =[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | education = [[Lehman College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Howard University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]])
[[Columbia University]] ([[Master of Public Administration|MPA]]) }} '''Letitia Ann James''' (born October 18, 1958) is an American lawyer and politician serving since 2019 as the [[Attorney General of New York]] (NYAG), having won the [[2018 New York Attorney General election|2018 election]] to succeed [[Barbara Underwood]]. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], James is the first [[African American]] and first woman to be elected New York Attorney General.{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2019/01/01/681364713/n-y-swears-in-new-attorney-general-after-a-tumultuous-year-for-the-office|title=N.Y. Swears In New Attorney General After A Tumultuous Year For The Office|last=Westerman|first=Ashley|date=January 1, 2019|work=NPR|access-date=January 1, 2019|archive-date=January 1, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190101103841/https://www.npr.org/2019/01/01/681364713/n-y-swears-in-new-attorney-general-after-a-tumultuous-year-for-the-office|url-status=live}}{{cite news |last1=Larson |first1=Erik |title=New York Versus the World: Letitia James Is Picking Big Fights |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-04/new-york-ag-letitia-james-fights-trump-nra-facebook-and-google |access-date=February 18, 2021 |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=February 4, 2021 |language=en}} Born and raised in [[Brooklyn]], James graduated from [[Lehman College]] in [[The Bronx]] before obtaining her [[Juris Doctor]] degree at [[Howard University]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] She worked as a [[public defender]], then on staff in the [[New York State Assembly]], and later as a New York State Assistant Attorney General in the Brooklyn regional office. James served as a member of the [[New York City Council]] from 2004 to 2013. She represented the [[New York City's 35th City Council district|35th district]], which includes the Brooklyn neighborhoods of [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn|Clinton Hill]], [[Fort Greene]], parts of [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]], [[Prospect Heights, Brooklyn|Prospect Heights]], and [[Bedford–Stuyvesant]]. James chaired the committees on economic development and sanitation and served on several others. From 2013 to 2018, she was the [[New York City Public Advocate]], making her the first African-American woman to be elected to and hold citywide office in New York City.{{Cite web |title=Alumna Letitia James Elected NYC Public Advocate, First African-American Woman to Hold Citywide Office |url=http://wp.lehman.edu/lehman-today/nyc-public-advocate-alumna-letitia-james-is-first-african-american-woman-to-hold-citywide-office/ |access-date=April 13, 2022 |language=en-US}} James was briefly a candidate in the [[2022 New York gubernatorial election]], but suspended her campaign in December 2021, opting to instead run for reelection as Attorney General. == Early life and education == Letitia Ann James was born on October 18, 1958, in [[Brooklyn]], New York.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323665504579027181873726784|title=Candidate's Age Often Listed Incorrectly|last=Kravitz|first=Derek|date=August 22, 2013|website=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=January 2, 2014|archive-date=March 21, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321055116/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323665504579027181873726784|url-status=live}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.martindale.com/new-york/new-york/letitia-ann-james-448146-a/ |title=Letitia Ann James Lawyer Profile on Martindale.com |access-date=October 5, 2019 |archive-date=November 23, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201123155306/https://www.martindale.com/attorney/letitia-ann-james-448146/ |url-status=live }}{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/12/19/new-yorks-next-attorney-general-targeted-slumlords-now-shes-going-after-trump/|title=New York's next attorney general targeted slumlords. Now she's going after Trump.|last=Phillips|first=Kristine|date=December 19, 2018|newspaper=The Washington Post|access-date=January 11, 2019|archive-date=January 11, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190111175415/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/12/19/new-yorks-next-attorney-general-targeted-slumlords-now-shes-going-after-trump/|url-status=live}} She is one of eight children born to Nellie James (b. 1919, [[Martinsville, Virginia]]){{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=THE CITY RECORD THE COUNCIL —STATED MEETING OF TUESDAY, MAY 25, 2010|url=https://www1.nyc.gov/assets/dcas/downloads/pdf/cityrecord/cityrecord-supplement-08-26-2010.pdf|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}} and Robert James.{{Cite web|last=Nielsen|first=Euell A.|title=Letitia A. James (1958- )|date=August 23, 2019|url=https://www.blackpast.org/african-american-history/letitia-a-james-1958/|access-date=January 30, 2021|language=en-US}} She attended New York City [[Public school (government funded)|public schools]]. Raised in [[Park Slope, Brooklyn]], she attended [[Fort Hamilton High School]] in nearby [[Bay Ridge]].{{Cite web|url=http://amsterdamnews.com/news/2018/dec/27/person-year-letitia-james/|title = Person of the Year: Letitia James|date = December 27, 2018}} She received her [[Bachelor of Arts]] from the [[City University of New York]]'s [[Lehman College]] in 1981, majoring in [[liberal arts]] with an emphasis in [[social work]].{{cite web|url=http://www1.cuny.edu/portal_ur/content/womens_leadership/alumnae/index.html|title=Distinguished CUNY Alumnae|publisher=The City University of New York|access-date=May 7, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817061930/http://www1.cuny.edu/portal_ur/content/womens_leadership/alumnae/index.html|archive-date=August 17, 2009|url-status=dead}} James received her [[Juris Doctor]] degree from [[Howard University School of Law]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] in 1987,{{cite web|url=https://dh.howard.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1135&context=hugradpro|title=1987 Howard University Commencement Program|publisher=Howard University|access-date=January 10, 2023|format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220524205244/https://dh.howard.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1135&context=hugradpro|archive-date=May 24, 2022|url-status=live}} and was admitted to practice law in New York State in 1989.{{cite web|url=http://council.nyc.gov/d35/html/members/home.shtml|title=District 35|website=Laurie A. Cumbo|access-date=September 13, 2017|archive-date=October 8, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008085334/http://council.nyc.gov/d35/html/members/home.shtml|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=http://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/attorney/AttorneyDetails?attorneyId=5455915|title=NYS Attorney Registration|access-date=September 24, 2013|archive-date=November 23, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201123155308/https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/attorneyservices/search?0|url-status=live}} As of 2013, James was enrolled at [[Columbia University]]'s [[School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University|School of International and Public Affairs]] (SIPA) in the [[Morningside Heights]] section of Manhattan, where she was working towards a [[Master of Public Administration]] degree.{{cite web|url=http://www.letitiajames2013.com/about_tish|title=About Tish|publisher=Letitia James 2013|access-date=September 16, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915085634/http://www.letitiajames2013.com/about_tish|archive-date=September 15, 2013|url-status=dead}} == Career == James served as a [[public defender]] for the [[Legal Aid Society]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nyccfb.info/public/voter-guide/general_2003/cd_statement/CD35_James_480.htm|title=2003 General Election Voter Guide: 35th City Council District|publisher=NYC Campaign Finance Board|access-date=September 16, 2013|archive-date=September 26, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926211209/http://www.nyccfb.info/public/voter-guide/general_2003/cd_statement/CD35_James_480.htm|url-status=live}} and established the Urban Network, a coalition of [[African-American]] professional organizations aimed at providing scholarships for inner city youth.{{cite web|url=http://wccny.org/2012/03/20/april-23-lunch-with-legislators-councilmember-letitia-james/|title=April 23 – Lunch with Legislators: Council Member Letitia James|publisher=Women's City Club of New York|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921060448/http://wccny.org/2012/03/20/april-23-lunch-with-legislators-councilmember-letitia-james/|archive-date=September 21, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nyccfb.info/public/voter-guide/primary_2013/cd_profile/PA_James_480.aspx|title=Candidates for Public Advocate: Democratic Primary|publisher=NYC Campaign Finance Board|access-date=September 20, 2013|archive-date=September 21, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921055757/http://www.nyccfb.info/public/voter-guide/primary_2013/cd_profile/PA_James_480.aspx|url-status=live}} She served on former New York Governor [[Mario Cuomo]]'s Task Force on [[Multiculturalism|Diversity]] in the Judiciary. She served as [[counsel]] for [[Albert Vann]], [[Chief of staff (politics)|Chief of Staff]] for [[Roger L. Green]] in the [[New York State Assembly]], and in the administration of [[New York Attorney General]] [[Eliot Spitzer]]. She was appointed the first Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Brooklyn regional office in 1999. While working in that position, James worked in many capacities but notably focused on consumer complaints involving [[predatory lending]] and other unlawful business practices. === 2001 and 2003 city council races === James' first run for the [[New York City's 35th City Council district|35th Council district]] was in November 2001. In a close race, James received 42% of the vote on the [[Working Families Party]] line but lost to [[James E. Davis (New York politician)|James E. Davis]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]. In July 2003, just months before the next election, Davis was assassinated by [[Othniel Askew]], a former political rival. Following Davis's death, his brother Geoffrey ran for his vacant council seat on the Democratic Party ticket, but on election day, November 4, 2003, Geoffrey A. Davis lost by a large margin to James as the Working Families Party nominee.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/05/nyregion/2003-election-city-council-letitia-james-wins-seat-that-slain-man-s-brother-felt.html|title=THE 2003 ELECTION: CITY COUNCIL; Letitia James Wins Seat That Slain Man's Brother Felt Was Rightfully His|first=Winnie|last=Hu|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 5, 2003|access-date=March 12, 2019|archive-date=May 28, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190528055901/https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/05/nyregion/2003-election-city-council-letitia-james-wins-seat-that-slain-man-s-brother-felt.html|url-status=live}} In that 2003 race, James officially became a member of the Working Families Party, and was the first citywide office-holder to run solely on the WFP line.{{cite web|url=https://politi.co/2s7GSnX|title=The rise of Tish James|first1=Laura|last1=Nahmias|first2=Gloria|last2=Pazmino|website=Politico PRO|access-date=March 12, 2019|archive-date=November 23, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201123155309/https://login.politicopro.com/?redirect=https://subscriber.politicopro.com/article/2018/05/23/the-rise-of-tish-james-433405|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=https://workingfamilies.org/2018/05/wfp-tish-james-zephyr-teachout/|title=WFP Gives Seal of Approval to Both Tish James and Zephyr Teachout for Attorney General|date=May 19, 2018|website=Working Families|access-date=March 12, 2019|archive-date=February 17, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190217120133/http://workingfamilies.org/2018/05/wfp-tish-james-zephyr-teachout/|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/19/nyregion/public-lives-only-the-party-is-minor-not-its-councilwoman.html|title=PUBLIC LIVES; Only the Party Is Minor, Not Its Councilwoman|first=Lynda|last=Richardson|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 19, 2003|access-date=March 12, 2019|archive-date=April 24, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190424223228/https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/19/nyregion/public-lives-only-the-party-is-minor-not-its-councilwoman.html|url-status=live}} === City council tenure === [[File:NLN Letitia James.jpg|upright|thumb|James speaking at [[New York City Hall|City Hall]], 2008]] James is the first member of the Working Families Party to win office in New York State, and the first [[third political party|third-party]] member to be elected to the city council since 1977.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/19/nyregion/public-lives-only-the-party-is-minor-not-its-councilwoman.html|title=Public Lives; Only the Party Is Minor, Not Its Councilwoman|newspaper=New York Times|author=Richardson, Lynda|date=November 19, 2003|access-date=February 19, 2017|archive-date=August 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816070049/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/19/nyregion/public-lives-only-the-party-is-minor-not-its-councilwoman.html|url-status=live}} She has since changed back to the Democratic party. James again won the Working Families and the Democratic parties' nominations by a large margin over Samuel Eric Blackwell, an urban planner at [[Long Island University]] and pro-stadium advocate. She was re-elected on the Democratic line on November 8, 2005, with 88.11% of the vote, compared to 6.80% for [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Anthony Herbert, and 5.08% for [[Independence Party of New York|Independence Party]] candidate Charles B. Billups.{{cite web|url=http://ny1.com/ny/Election/2005election/index.html?page_name=brooklyn|title=Election 2005|publisher=[[NY1]]|access-date=November 9, 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060328094812/http://ny1.com/ny/Election/2005election/index.html?page_name=brooklyn|archive-date=March 28, 2006|url-status=dead}} On October 10, 2006, there was a devastating fire at the [[Broken Angel House]], an architectural icon in [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn]]. The fire attracted attention from the [[New York City Department of Buildings]], which resulted in citations being issued for numerous building code violations. James represented Broken Angel's owner, Arthur Wood, [[Pro bono publico|pro bono]] in his negotiations to keep his home. The agency decided to allow Wood to re-occupy Broken Angel provided the upper levels were taken down and the central stairwell reconstructed.{{cite news|url=http://www.brooklynpapers.com/html/issues/_vol30/30_01/30_01nets3.html|title='Angel' on the market: Clinton Hill amalgam is yours for $1.5 mil|publisher=[[The Brooklyn Papers]]|author=Rubinstein, Dana|date=January 6, 2007|access-date=January 6, 2007|archive-date=January 8, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070108110837/http://www.brooklynpapers.com/html/issues/_vol30/30_01/30_01nets3.html|url-status=live}} [[File:Council Member Letitia James.jpg|thumb|left|James in the [[New York City Council]] in 2009]] She was the first to question cost overruns and irregularities in the subcontracting work of the new CityTime payroll system much touted by Bloomberg which eventually led to several indictments, Bloomberg asking a tech giant for $600 million back, and two consultants fleeing the country in 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/137041-citytime-payroll-manager-fired-over-pay-scandal/|title=CityTime Payroll Manager Fired Over Pay Scandal|publisher=WNYC|access-date=September 19, 2013|archive-date=September 21, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921061251/http://www.wnyc.org/story/137041-citytime-payroll-manager-fired-over-pay-scandal/|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/450-million-fraud-citytime-husband-wife-team-flee-country-leaving-200-employees-lurch-article-1.130227|title=$450 million Fraud: CityTime husband and wife team flee country leaving 200 employees in the lurch|newspaper=New York Daily News|access-date=September 19, 2013|archive-date=September 21, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921061630/http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/450-million-fraud-citytime-husband-wife-team-flee-country-leaving-200-employees-lurch-article-1.130227|url-status=live}} James originally advocated for the demolition of the [[Second Empire (architecture)|Second Empire]] houses on [[Admiral's Row]] in order to build a parking lot for a proposed supermarket to serve residents in nearby housing developments, but later supported preserving some of the historic housing.{{cite news|url=http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/31/27/31_27_mm_admirals_row.html|title=James gets in middle of 'Row'|newspaper=The Brooklyn Paper|author=McLaughlin, Mike|date=July 15, 2008|access-date=September 25, 2008|archive-date=August 21, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821170944/http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/31/27/31_27_mm_admirals_row.html|url-status=live}} In 2008, James, with [[Bill de Blasio]], advocated against Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]]'s attempts to seek a third term without a voter referendum.{{cite news|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/10/06/an-emerging-voice-in-term-limits-debate|title=Councilman Balks at Procedure to Change Term Limits|work=City Blogs|publisher=New York Times|author=Hicks, Jonathan P.|date=October 16, 2008|access-date=October 20, 2008|archive-date=October 27, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081027203746/http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/10/06/an-emerging-voice-in-term-limits-debate/|url-status=live}} James won the Democratic [[Primary election|primary]] in September 2009 against her opponents, community organizer Delia Hunley-Adossa,[http://fort-greene.thelocal.nytimes.com/2009/09/15/james-in-a-landslide/ "James, in a landslide"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714223654/http://fort-greene.thelocal.nytimes.com/2009/09/15/james-in-a-landslide/ |date=July 14, 2011 }}. Newman, Andy (September 15, 2009) The Local who received more than $200,000 from Forest City Ratner{{cite news|url=http://fort-greene.thelocal.nytimes.com/2009/08/27/the-day-hunley-adossa-group-got-more-than-200g-from-ratner/|title=The Day: Hunley-Adossa Group Got More than 200G from Ratner|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=September 19, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921061437/http://fort-greene.thelocal.nytimes.com/2009/08/27/the-day-hunley-adossa-group-got-more-than-200g-from-ratner/|archive-date=September 21, 2013|url-status=dead}} and Medhanie Estiphanos, a financial consultant. James went on to win re-election for a second term. In May 2013, with a group that included construction unions, community groups and other elected officials, she was a part of an Article 78 lawsuit against the [[Bloomberg administration]] and Acadia Realty Trust seeking the shut-down of the City Point real estate project and a reassessment of its environmental impact.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.cityandstateny.com/pols-james-mosley-lend-support-to-city-point-lawsuit/|title=Pols James, Mosley Lend Support To City Point Lawsuit|magazine=City & State|access-date=September 16, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002025126/http://www.cityandstateny.com/pols-james-mosley-lend-support-to-city-point-lawsuit/|archive-date=October 2, 2013|url-status=dead}} In June 2016, James attempted to pressure six [[financial institution]]s, including [[BB&T]], Berkshire Bank, [[Citizens Financial Group]], [[People's United Financial|People's United Bank]], [[Regions Financial Corporation]] and [[TD Bank, N.A.|TD Bank]], into ending its practice of providing [[financial services]] to gun manufacturers.{{cite news|url=http://pubadvocate.nyc.gov/news/articles/pa-james-calls-six-banks-terminate-financial-backing-sig-sauer-maker-gun-used-orlando/|title=PA James Calls on Six Banks to Terminate Financial Backing of Sig Sauer, Maker of Gun Used in Orlando Massacre|publisher=Public Advocate for the City of New York|access-date=July 18, 2016|archive-date=June 28, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160628212234/http://pubadvocate.nyc.gov/news/articles/pa-james-calls-six-banks-terminate-financial-backing-sig-sauer-maker-gun-used-orlando|url-status=live}} [[BB&T]] was specifically requested to drop the accounts of [[SIG Sauer]] of [[New Hampshire]], but denied the request.{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/business/business_news/local/bb-t-doesn-t-agree-to-drop-sig-sauer-firearm/article_bdee92b0-f181-5c82-afbb-624bb8d7d220.html|title=BB&T doesn't agree to drop Sig Sauer firearm accounts|newspaper=Winston-Salem Journal|access-date=July 18, 2016|archive-date=August 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816010318/http://www.journalnow.com/business/business_news/local/bb-t-doesn-t-agree-to-drop-sig-sauer-firearm/article_bdee92b0-f181-5c82-afbb-624bb8d7d220.html|url-status=live}} ==== Committee assignments ==== *Committee on Economic Development (chair) *Committee on Sanitation (chair) *Committee on Parks & Recreation *Committee on Small Business *Committee on Technology in Government *Committee on Veteran Affairs *Committee on Women's Issues[http://www.gothamgazette.com/article/searchlight/20100122/203/3159] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212224119/http://www.gothamgazette.com/article/searchlight/20100122/203/3159|date=February 12, 2010}}. Gross, Courtney. (January 22, 2010) "Stated Meeting: The Council's New Order" === Public Advocate === {{Main|2013 New York City Public Advocate election}} [[File:Letitia James at March for Our Lives NYC.jpg|thumb|James at the 2018 NYC [[March For Our Lives]] rally]] In 2013, James ran for [[New York City Public Advocate]] and received 36% of the vote in the first Democratic primary, under the 40% threshold that would have avoided a [[two-round system|runoff election]]. James won the runoff election on October 1, 2013, against [[Daniel Squadron]], 59.4%–40.6%, becoming the party's nominee for the city's elected watchdog position in November.Saul, Michael Howard [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303918804579110161609620416 "Letitia James Wins Public Advocate Runoff"] ''The Wall Street Journal'', October 1, 2013. Retrieved May 6, 2024. In the 2013 election campaign for Public Advocate, James was endorsed by many of the city's important labor unions, [[National Organization for Women|NOW]], [[Planned Parenthood]], Democracy for NYC, [[League of Conservation Voters]], ''[[Amsterdam News]]'' and ''[[El Diario La Prensa|El Diario]].''{{Cite web |title=Join with Planned Parenthood, Gloria Steinem and NOW in NYC |url=https://www.dailykos.com/story/2013/9/24/1240977/-Join-with-Planned-Parenthood-Gloria-Steinem-and-NOW-in-NYC |date= September 24, 2013|access-date=May 23, 2022 |website=[[Daily Kos]]}} On October 1, 2013, James achieved a Democratic primary win in spite of her campaign fundraising trailing [[Daniel Squadron]]'s and [[Reshma Saujani]],{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/politics/2013/05/8530470/shunning-squadron-brooklyn-democratic-organization-backs-letitia-ja|title=Shunning Squadron, the Brooklyn Democratic organization backs Letitia James|publisher=Capital|access-date=September 20, 2013|archive-date=September 21, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921053551/http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/politics/2013/05/8530470/shunning-squadron-brooklyn-democratic-organization-backs-letitia-ja|url-status=live}} to become the Democratic Party's nominee for New York City's elected watchdog position. She was endorsed by third-place finisher Saujani in September{{cite web|url=http://www.letitiajames2013.com/reshma_saujani_endorses_letitia_james|title=Reshma Saujani endorses Letitia James|publisher=Letitia James campaign|access-date=September 25, 2013|archive-date=September 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928042948/http://www.letitiajames2013.com/reshma_saujani_endorses_letitia_james|url-status=live}} James won the Democratic [[two-round system|runoff election]].{{cite news|url=http://project.wnyc.org/election2013/|title=Election 2013: Other Races|access-date=September 16, 2013|archive-date=November 23, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201123155311/https://project.wnyc.org/election2013/|url-status=live}} Without a Republican opponent, she won the general election with over 83% of the vote.{{cite web|title=Letitia James wins NYC Public Advocate Democratic runoff |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/politics&id=9268206 |publisher=WABC TV |access-date=October 2, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005082244/http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news%2Fpolitics&id=9268206 |archive-date= October 5, 2013 }} In 2017, James won the Democratic primary for her position with 77% of the vote, over closest competitor David Eisenbach's 23%.{{cite web|url=http://www.gothamgazette.com/city/7190-2017-new-york-city-primary-election-results|title=2017 New York City Primary Election Results|first=Ben|last=Max|work=[[Gotham Gazette]]|date=September 13, 2017|access-date=September 13, 2017|archive-date=September 13, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170913182737/http://www.gothamgazette.com/city/7190-2017-new-york-city-primary-election-results|url-status=live}} == New York State Attorney General == === 2018 election === {{Main|2018 New York Attorney General election}} In May 2018, James, who initially planned to run for [[Mayor of New York City]] in [[2021 New York City mayoral election|2021]],{{Cite news|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=dhH_nLfPUVU&feature=youtu.be|title=Tish James On Her Run for Attorney General, Boosting Our Communities, And Speaking Truth To Power|access-date=April 24, 2020|language=en|archive-date=November 23, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201123155309/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dhH_nLfPUVU&feature=youtu.be&app=desktop|url-status=live}} declared her candidacy for [[Attorney General of New York]] and won the Democratic primary on September 13, 2018, with 40.6% of the vote; she defeated [[Zephyr Teachout]] (31%) and two other candidates.{{cite news|first1=William|last1=Neuman|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/24/nyregion/nyc-2021-mayor-election-candidates.html|title=No Need to Flash-Forward to 2021: Mayoral Hopefuls Already Engaged|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 24, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180921034221/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/24/nyregion/nyc-2021-mayor-election-candidates.html |archive-date=September 21, 2018|accessdate=September 20, 2018}}{{Cite news|first=Jeffery C.|last=Mays|date=September 13, 2018|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/13/nyregion/letitia-james-attorney-general.html|title=Letitia James Makes History by Winning Attorney General Primary in New York|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=September 15, 2018|language=en|archive-date=September 14, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180914134746/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/13/nyregion/letitia-james-attorney-general.html|url-status=live}} On November 6, 2018, she was elected Attorney General, defeating Republican [[Keith Wofford]].{{Cite news|first=Jeffery C.|last=Mays| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/06/nyregion/letitia-james-wins-ny-ag.html| title = Breaking Barriers, Letitia James Is Elected New York Attorney General| newspaper = [[The New York Times]]| date = November 6, 2018| access-date = November 7, 2018| archive-date = November 7, 2018| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181107054159/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/06/nyregion/letitia-james-wins-ny-ag.html| url-status = live}} She made history by becoming the first woman and African American to be elected as attorney general in New York and serve in that role. During her campaign, James vowed to pursue [[Donald Trump]], who she said was an “illegitimate president” and an “embarrassment.”{{cite web | url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/09/21/james-lawsuit-trump-longstanding-battle-00058128 | title=Tish James just sued Trump — but they've been at it for years | website=[[Politico]] | date=September 21, 2022 }} === Tenure === [[File:Letitia James at New York Pride 50 - 2019-348 (48166918552) (1).jpg|upright|thumb|James marching in June 2019 at [[Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019]]]] James was sworn in as attorney general on January 1, 2019, succeeding [[Barbara Underwood]], who was first appointed after the resignation of [[Eric Schneiderman]].{{cite news |agency=[[The Associated Press]] |work=WAMC |title=James Sworn In As NY Attorney General |date=January 1, 2019 |access-date=January 1, 2019 |url=https://www.wamc.org/post/james-sworn-ny-attorney-general |archive-date=January 1, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190101115634/https://www.wamc.org/post/james-sworn-ny-attorney-general |url-status=live }} === Suit against All Faiths Cemetery === In September 2019, James filed suit against the officials of [[Queens]]'s [[All Faiths Cemetery]], alleging financial misconduct.{{Cite web |last=Griffin |first=Allie |date=September 4, 2019 |title=Board Members of Non-Profit Cemetery Embezzled Thousands of Dollars |url=https://ridgewoodpost.com/board-members-of-non-profit-cemetery-embezzled-thousands-of-dollars |access-date=April 18, 2023 |website=ridgewoodpost.com |language=en-US |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220207170549/https://ridgewoodpost.com/board-members-of-non-profit-cemetery-embezzled-thousands-of-dollars |archive-date=February 7, 2022 |url-status=live}} === State civil suit against the NRA === In August 2020, James filed a civil lawsuit in [[New York Supreme Court]] against the [[National Rifle Association of America]] (NRA), accusing the organization of corruption and financial misconduct, and calling for its dissolution.[[PBS NewsHour]], {{YouTube|zXFgj2935Ec|New York Attorney General Letitia James files lawsuit to dissolve NRA}}, August 6, 2020{{Cite news |last=Hakim |first=Danny |date=August 6, 2020 |title=New York Attorney General Sues N.R.A. and Seeks Its Closure |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/06/us/ny-nra-lawsuit-letitia-james.html |access-date=February 5, 2023 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200806180804/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/06/us/ny-nra-lawsuit-letitia-james.html |archive-date=August 6, 2020 |url-status=live}} The NRA filed a countersuit against James, citing statements she made during her 2018 campaign.{{cite web|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/08/19/nra-lawsuit-ny-ag-letitia-james-past-comments/5606437002/|title=NY AG Letitia James called the NRA a 'terrorist organization.' Will it hurt her case?|last=Campbell|first=Jon|date=August 19, 2020|website=[[USA Today]]|access-date=August 29, 2020|archive-date=October 31, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201031225301/https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/08/19/nra-lawsuit-ny-ag-letitia-james-past-comments/5606437002/|url-status=live}} In February 2024, a lawsuit brought by the New York Attorney General’s Office under James found that the NRA mismanaged charitable funds when it failed to stop top executives, including CEO Wayne LaPierre, from diverting millions of dollars for lavish personal trips, no-show contracts and other questionable expenditures. A jury found that LaPierre should pay the gun rights group $4.3 million in damages for mismanagement and misspending of charitable funds, having violated his fiduciary duties from 2014 to 2022. The panel also found the NRA’s former CFO Wilson Phillips should pay back $2 million for breaching his fiduciary duties as an executive. {{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/02/23/us/nra-trial-verdict-new-york/index.html|title=NRA found liable in corruption case as jury says longtime leader Wayne LaPierre should repay $4.3 million|last=Souza|first=Sabrina|date=February 23, 2024|website=[[CNN]]|access-date=February 23, 2024}} ===Investigation into state COVID-19 response=== In early March 2020, the attorney general's office began to preliminarily "investigate allegations of [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19]]-related neglect of residents in nursing homes."{{cite web |title=Nursing Home Response to COVID-19 Pandemic |url=https://ag.ny.gov/sites/default/files/2021-nursinghomesreport.pdf |website=Office of the New York State Attorney General |access-date=29 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210128150522/https://ag.ny.gov/sites/default/files/2021-nursinghomesreport.pdf |archive-date=28 January 2021 |language=en-US |date=January 2021 |url-status=live}} The office solicited and subsequently received 953 complaints from patients' families regarding neglect of patients through November 16. The probe released its first report on both the nursing homes and the state [[New York State Department of Health|Department of Health]] (DOH) on January 28, 2021, where it concluded that the department's public data under-counted nursing home deaths by up to 50 percent.{{Cite press release|url=https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/2021/attorney-general-james-releases-report-nursing-homes-response-covid-19|title = Attorney General James Releases Report on Nursing Homes' Response to COVID-19|publisher=Laetitia James, NY Attorney General|date=January 28, 2021}} The methodology of the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) was to compare deaths from COVID reported to the DOH and such deaths reported to OAG. The OAG press release makes no mention of medical analysis of the cases. James said investigations into 20 separate nursing homes "whose reported conduct during the first wave of the pandemic presented particular concern" would continue for the foreseeable future. The report was heralded by some in Albany as a "declaration of independence" from New York State Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] after a two-year alliance in opposition to President [[Donald Trump]].{{Cite web|first=Anna|last=Gronewold|url=https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2021/03/11/tish-james-andrew-cuomo-investigation-new-york-attorney-general-474381|title='It's a Kill Shot': How Tish James Holds Cuomo's Future in Her Hands|website=[[Politico]]|date=March 10, 2021}} Three weeks after the report, the ''[[Times Union (Albany)|Albany Times-Union]]'' revealed an ongoing joint investigation by the FBI and the [[United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York]], examining how Governor Cuomo's coronavirus task force played a role in nursing homes' COVID-19 response.{{Cite news|last=Lyons|first=Brendan J.|date=February 17, 2021|title=FBI, U.S. attorney in Brooklyn probing Cuomo administration on nursing homes|url=https://www.timesunion.com/news/article/cuomo-investigation-fbi-covid-nursing-homes-15957401.php|access-date=March 19, 2021|website=[[Times Union (Albany)|Times Union]]|language=en-US}} On March 18, 2021, ''[[The City (website)|The City]]'' found that the FBI's scope included a last-minute addition to the state's 2020 budget that provided greater immunity to long-term care organizations.{{Cite web|last=Velasquez|first=Josefa|date=March 18, 2021|title=FBI Cuomo Probe Seeks Details on Deal to Shield Nursing Homes from COVID Lawsuits|url=https://www.thecity.nyc/2021/3/18/22338838/fbi-cuomo-probe-nursing-homes-covid-lawsuits|access-date=March 19, 2021|website=[[The City (website)|The City]]|language=en}} The head of the Greater New York Hospital Association said in an August 2020 [[New York State Senate]] hearing that the lobbying group had provided a "draft" of "some ideas to be included" to the governor's office.{{Cite web|date=October 7, 2020|title=Public Hearing 08-12-20 Senate COVID-19 and Hospitals FINAL.txt|url=https://www.nysenate.gov/transcripts/public-hearing-08-12-20-senate-covid-19-and-hospitals-finaltxt|url-status=dead|access-date=March 19, 2021|website=NY State Senate|pages=208–211|language=en|archive-date=October 28, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028140106/https://www.nysenate.gov/transcripts/public-hearing-08-12-20-senate-covid-19-and-hospitals-finaltxt}} === Report on Andrew Cuomo sexual harassment=== {{Further|Andrew Cuomo sexual harassment allegations}} On August 3, 2021, James' office released a report finding that Cuomo engaged in multiple acts of sexual harassment.{{Cite web|last=Sneed|first=Tierney|date=August 3, 2021|title=New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo sexually harassed multiple women, state attorney general report says|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/03/politics/andrew-cuomo-new-york-report/index.html|access-date=August 4, 2021|website=[[CNN]]|language=en}} === 2022 Democratic primary for governor === On October 29, 2021, James stated her intention to run for the office of [[Governor of New York]] in the 2022 Democratic primary{{Cite news|last=Glueck|first=Katie|date=October 29, 2021|title=Letitia James Declares Her Candidacy for N.Y. Governor|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/29/nyregion/letitia-james-governor.html|access-date=October 29, 2021|issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite web|last=Velasquez|first=Josefa|date=October 27, 2021|title=Attorney General Letitia James Poised to Announce Run for Governor, Sources Say|url=https://www.thecity.nyc/politics/2021/10/27/22749599/letitia-james-announce-governor|access-date=October 27, 2021|website=[[The City (website)|The City]]|language=en}} but withdrew from the race in December, after consistently polling behind incumbent Governor [[Kathy Hochul]], with James instead choosing to seek reelection as Attorney General.{{cite news |url = https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/city-hall/story/2021/12/09/james-drops-out-of-governors-race-1399022|title = James drops out of New York governor's race|work = [[Politico]]|date = December 9, 2021|access-date = January 19, 2022|last = Mahoney|first = Bill}} === 2022 election === {{Main|2022 New York Attorney General election}} After James launched her reelection bid, all previous Democratic candidates withdrew their candidacies and endorsed her.{{Cite tweet|last=Williams|first=Zach|user=ZachReports|title=Vullo drops out of 2022 Democratic primary for AG|url=https://twitter.com/zachreports/status/1470399983568498689|url-status=live|date=December 13, 2021|access-date=December 13, 2021|website=[[Twitter]]|number=1470399983568498689|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211213142909/https://twitter.com/ZachReports/status/1470399983568498689 |archive-date=December 13, 2021 }}{{Cite web|title=Vanel Suspends NY AG Campaign Announcement|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3xP25yXGxGA|access-date=December 13, 2021|website=YouTube|language=en}}{{cite tweet|first=Zephyr|last=Teachout|authorlink=Zephyr Teachout|user=ZephyrTeachout|url=https://twitter.com/ZephyrTeachout/status/1470128996998422528|title=My full statement on my campaign is below, but most importantly, thank you, New York|number=1470128996998422528|website=[[Twitter]]|date=December 12, 2021}}{{cite tweet|first=Morgan|last=McKay|user=morganfmckay|url=https://twitter.com/morganfmckay/status/1469024453229260802|title=Now that NYS Attorney General @TishJames has decided not to run for Governor and will run for re-election, Attorney General candidate and Senator Shelley Mayer drops out of the AG race|website=[[Twitter]]|number=1469024453229260802|date=December 9, 2021}}{{Cite web|first1=Jake|last1=Offenhartz|first2=Jon|last2=Campbell|url=https://gothamist.com/news/new-york-attorney-general-letitia-james-drops-out-of-governors-race|title = New York Attorney General Letitia James Drops Out of Governor's Race|work=[[Gothamist]]|date = December 9, 2021}} On November 8, 2022, James was reelected Attorney General, defeating Republican Michael Henry in the general election. ===NFL investigation=== On May 4, 2023, James and her California counterpart [[Rob Bonta]] announced they would jointly investigate the [[National Football League]] over employment practices at its offices in [[New York City]] and [[Los Angeles]], citing a report by ''[[The New York Times]]'' detailing complaints of harassment and discrimination made by former female staffers.{{cite web | url=https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/2023/attorneys-general-james-and-bonta-launch-investigation-national-football-leagues | title=Attorneys General James and Bonta Launch Investigation into National Football League's Workplace Practices and Culture | date=May 4, 2023 }} ===2024 Trump lawsuit in New York=== {{Main|New York civil investigation of The Trump Organization}} In 2022, in her capacity as New York Attorney General, James filed a civil lawsuit against [[the Trump Organization]] and worked alongside the [[New York County District Attorney|Manhattan district attorney]]'s office in its [[New York criminal investigation of The Trump Organization|criminal investigation of the organization]].{{cite news |date=January 19, 2022 |title=New York's attorney general says Trump's company misled banks, tax officials |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/01/19/1074000357/new-yorks-attorney-general-says-trumps-company-misled-banks-tax-officials |access-date=January 23, 2022 |work=[[NPR]] |agency=[[The Associated Press]]}} Trump argued that previous comments by James, including referring to him as an 'illegitimate president' during her campaign for attorney general, prove that she has a political [[Feud|vendetta]] against him.{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-63000691 | title=Letitia James and Donald Trump's history of clashes | date=September 22, 2022 }} On February 16, 2024, the fraud case against the former president, [[Donald Trump]], proved successful. Judge [[Arthur Engoron]]'s 92-page ruling barred Trump from operating any business in New York for three years and fined him more than $355 million.{{Cite web |last=Christobek |first=Kate |date=February 16, 2024 |title= The Civil Fraud Ruling on Donald Trump, Annotated |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/02/16/nyregion/trump-fraud-engoron-decision-annotated.html |access-date=February 24, 2024 |website=nytimes.com}}{{Cite web |date=February 16, 2024 |title=Attorney General James Wins Landmark Victory in Case Against Donald Trump |url=https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/2024/attorney-general-james-wins-landmark-victory-case-against-donald-trump |access-date=February 24, 2024 |website=ny.gov}} == Personal life == James lives in the [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn|Clinton Hill]] neighborhood of Brooklyn and is a member of [[Emmanuel Baptist Church (Brooklyn)|Emmanuel Baptist Church]].{{cite news |last1=Mena |first1=Kelly |title=State AG "Tish" James Brings It Home To God And Community |url=https://www.kingscountypolitics.com/state-ag-tish-james-brings-it-home-to-god-and-community/ |access-date=February 18, 2021 |work=Kings County Politics |date=January 9, 2019}}{{cite news |last1=Manskar |first1=Noah |title=Local Legend: NY's Top Lawyer Tish James Talks Clinton Hill |url=https://patch.com/new-york/fortgreene/local-legend-tish-james-impromptu-clinton-hill-traffic-cop |access-date=February 18, 2021 |work=[[Patch (website)|Patch]] |date=August 30, 2019 |language=en}} At a May 2022 rally, James stated that she had received an abortion early in her tenure as a member of the New York City Council. James said, "'I was just elected and I was faced with the decision of whether to have an abortion or not, and I chose to have an abortion. I walked proudly into Planned Parenthood, and I make no apologies to anyone'".{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/ny-attorney-general-letitia-james-i-chose-to-have-an-abortion-years-ago/3673421/|title=‘No Apologies:' NY AG Letitia James Tells Protesters ‘I Chose to Have an Abortion'|website=nbcnewyork.com|date=May 4, 2022}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cityandstateny.com/policy/2022/05/letitia-james-backs-proposed-abortion-care-grant-program/366686/|title=Letitia James backs proposed abortion care grant program|date=May 9, 2022|website=City & State NY|last=Lewis|first=Rebecca}}{{Cite web|url=https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/i-make-no-apologies-democrat-ny-ag-reveals-she-proudly-got-abortion-new-york-attorney-general-letitia-james-roe-wade-scotus-supreme-court-planned-parenthood-kathy-hochul|title='I make no apologies': Democratic NY AG reveals she 'proudly' got abortion|last=Rogers|first=Zachary|date=May 4, 2022|website=The National Desk}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/attorney-general-letitia-james-abortion-experience_n_6273d876e4b03ca8363e3a24|title=New York Attorney General Shares Her Own Abortion Story With 'No Apologies To Anyone'|date=May 5, 2022|website=HuffPost|last=Golgowski|first=Nina}} ==Electoral history== ===New York City Council=== {{Election box begin no change|title=2001 New York City Council's 35th district Democratic primary{{cite web|title=F0202 2001 PRIMARY ELECTION October 11, 2001|url=https://vote.nyc/sites/default/files/downloads/pdf/results/2001/primaryelection/2001p.pdf|website=vote.nyc|access-date=June 11, 2020|archive-date=June 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200612003849/https://vote.nyc/sites/default/files/downloads/pdf/results/2001/primaryelection/2001p.pdf|url-status=live}}}} {{Election box winning candidate with party link no change|candidate=[[James E.
